issue.title: Run parameter optimization on Spark

labels.name: topic: parallelism
labels.description: Related with parallelism and distributed experiments.

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
Hi Team,
Do you have any plan to add some functionality to run this on Spark?
Do you have any recommendation to do the optimization in parallel?
Best,
Ana

body:
This might be a stupid idea, but I used to do distributed tensorflow hyperparameters with Dask.

It can distribute workloads via ssh, and allows you to serialize python objects and send them over to other machines. It also has a console to manage workers.

The interface is super simple. You just provide a python function and a list of parameters to Dask, and it uses a variety of ways to distribute it across machines. Dask also handles the distribution of data, provided that your data is stored in `pandas.DataFrame`.

Dask is a work in progress though. 

Check out their website here https://dask.org/
@renxida would you be open to creating an example notebook for using Dask with Talos?

body: Another option related with this is to simply use https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/distributed_training

issue.title: [RFC00101] Support for Distributed Experiment

repository.name: jako
repository.description: Parallelization of Hyperparameter Experiments with Talos

issue.body:
## Background

At times it's beneficial to be able to distribute the experiment to more than one host. A typical use-case is where the researcher has access to more than one host machines on a local network or then in a cloud environment such as AWS.

## Guiding Principles

- Use a modern distribution library for python
- It must allow distribution of experiments without changing any of the current Talos codes
- It must live in the `talos` namespace as `talos.distribute` or `talos.Distribute`

## How will it work

Right now Talos experiment works in the following way: 

A.1) The experiment consists of a given number of permutations to go through
A.2) After each permutation, a log entry is made onto the host (local or otherwise) running the experiment
A.3) At the end of the experiment, the results can be viewed in the experiment log (a CSV file)

The way a distributed Talos experiment works: 

B.1) The experiment consists of a given number of permutations to go through (let this `P`)
B.2) The experiment is distributed across a given number of machines (let this be `D`)
B.3) Each individual machine will handle `P`/`D` randomly picked permutations 
B.4) Each individual machine will operate exactly as in `A.1` through `A.3`
B.5) At the end of the experiment, the experiment logs from each individual machine are combined into one file

Other than the permutations, each individual machine follows the logic exactly as instructed in `talos.Scan()` to start the experiment. 

`talos.Distribute()` should accept as its input, `talos.Scan()` in where the experiment is configured following the Talos way. `talos.Distribute()` should only accept arguments that are directly related with the distribution.

## Central Datastore

Whatever is logged in the `experiment_log` CSV during the experiment, is updated in a central psql datastore. This can be every minute or a continuous stream based on updates in the CSVs on each node. Note that a `model_id` must be generated based on the row number in the CSV combined with a `node_id` so it becomes a unique identifier of the model in the central datastore.

NOTE: It's useful here to keep in mind that we want to later implement epoch-by-epoch updates live from a Callback. So with that in mind, we might also look at something like MaterializeDB as the next step.

## What this is not

- It is not a way to distribute TensorFlow model training
- It is not a way to distribute Talos experiments on a single host machine (which is handled in autonomio/talos#55)

## Historically related Issues

NOTE: These are provided simply as a historical reference, not as a guide.

- autonomio/talos#100
- autonomio/talos#131 
- autonomio/talos#332
